title: Jefferson Boulevard
text:
Jefferson Boulevard is a street in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a> and <a href="Culver%20City%2C%20California">Culver City, California</a>. Its eastern terminus is at <a href="Central%20Avenue%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">Central Avenue</a> east of <a href="Exposition%20Park%20%28Los%20Angeles%29">Exposition Park</a>. At its entrance to Culver City, it splits with National Boulevard. North of <a href="Sawtelle%20Boulevard">Sawtelle Boulevard</a>, it merges with <a href="Sepulveda%20Boulevard">Sepulveda Boulevard</a>. Jefferson returns before <a href="Slauson%20Avenue">Slauson Avenue</a> and ends at Culver Boulevard; its western terminus is near <a href="Playa%20Del%20Rey%2C%20California">Playa Del Rey</a>.
Education and transportation.
<a href="University%20of%20Southern%20California">University of Southern California (USC)</a> is located on Jefferson Boulevard from <a href="Figueroa%20Street">Figueroa Street</a> to <a href="Vermont%20Avenue">Vermont Avenue</a>. Its sports center complex, the <a href="Galen%20Center">Galen Center</a>, is located at the southeast corner of Jefferson and Figueroa.
Bus service is operated through Jefferson Boulevard between Playa Vista and West L.A. Transit Center by <a href="Culver%20City%20Transit">Culver City Transit</a> line 4, between West LA Transit Center and USC by Metro Local line 38, and east of USC by Metro Local line 102. The <a href="E%20Line%20%28Los%20Angeles%20Metro%29">Metro E Line</a> serves two light rail stations at Jefferson: <a href="Jefferson/USC%20%28LACMTA%20station%29">one</a> at Flower Street near USC and the <a href="La%20Cienega/Jefferson%20%28LACMTA%20station%29">other</a> on <a href="La%20Cienega%20Boulevard">La Cienega Boulevard</a>.
Little New Orleans.
Los Angeles saw an influx of <a href="Louisiana%20Creole%20people">Louisiana Creole people</a> to the area in the mid-1900s, to the point that by the 1950s a portion of Jefferson Boulevard and <a href="Jefferson%20Park%2C%20Los%20Angeles">Jefferson Park</a> (a neighborhood that ran partially along Jefferson Boulevard) was unofficially dubbed "Little <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a>". The population was predominantly Creole and held many Creole-owned businesses such as the Big Loaf Bakery, which was considered to be the "only place in Los Angeles that made New Orleans style <a href="Baguettes">Baguettes</a>".
